title: 105_hr4240
content: The Act is titled the "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" and addresses liability for computer date failure. The "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" addresses liability for computer date failure in cases where only contractual damages for business loss and repair costs can be sought if certain conditions are met, excluding personal injury claims. The defendant must provide notice to buyers of computer system components experiencing date failure and offer free repairs for products sold after December 31, 1994. The defendant must provide notice on their website and offer free repairs for computer system components sold after December 31, 1994, that are involved in date failure. The defendant must provide notice on their website and offer free repairs for computer system components sold before January 1, 1995, that may experience a computer date failure. The notice should explain how buyers can obtain repair or replacement if available, or additional information on the system, component, program, or software. This does not limit contracting parties' ability to enter into agreements. The subsection allows for repair or replacement of computer systems, components, programs, or software. It does not limit liability agreements between contracting parties. The term "person" refers to those engaged in commerce. "Under a special rule, actions against persons not engaged in commerce due to computer date failure are contract-based, allowing recovery for business losses and repair costs if no personal injury is involved." The plaintiff must not have suffered personal injury from the computer date failure, and the defendant must have made efforts to prevent the failure and tested their systems before July 1, 1999. The defendant must have tested its systems by simulating the transition to the Year 2000 before July 1, 1999, and provided notice of their efforts to prevent a computer date failure by August 1, 1999. The defendant must have tested its systems by simulating the transition to the Year 2000 before July 1, 1999, and provided notice of their efforts to prevent a computer date failure by August 1, 1999. The President's Council on the Year 2000 Conversion shall make available the notice it received on the Council's homepage on the worldwide web. The President's Council on the Year 2000 Conversion will publish received notices on its website. Contracting parties are not limited in their ability to make agreements on liability and damages from computer date failures. Definitions include actions for damages from date failures, breach of contract, shareholder actions, and failure to detect or report date failures. The term "action" refers to legal actions related to damages from computer date failures, breach of contract, shareholder actions, and failure to detect or report date failures. A "computer date failure" is defined as the inability of a computer system or program to accurately process data between the years 1999 and 2000 and beyond. The term "computer program or software" refers to a set of instructions used in a computer to achieve a specific result. A "computer system" includes electronic devices, networks, and support devices, excluding non-programmable calculators. A computer system consists of electronic devices, networks, and support devices that contain computer programs or electronic instructions to perform functions such as logic, arithmetic, data processing, storage, communication, and control. SEC. 3. TEMPORARY ANTITRUST EXEMPTION. Antitrust laws do not apply to conduct aimed at addressing computer date failure until December 31, 2001, except in cases of boycott. The term "antitrust laws" is defined as per the Clayton Act. The term "antitrust laws" is defined as per the Clayton Act, including section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act and any State laws similar to those mentioned.
